headline.print_headline: India Prosperity Creates Paradox; Many Children Are Fat, Even More Are Famished
headline.main: India Prosperity Creates Paradox; Many Children Are Fat, Even More Are Famished

docs.lead_paragraph: While India’s health officials confront rising levels of childhood obesity, gnawing destitution continues to plague millions of its youngest citizens.
docs.snippet: While India’s health officials confront rising levels of childhood obesity, gnawing destitution continues to plague millions of its youngest citizens.

headline.print_headline: Ten Suggestions for Rescuing the Bush Legacy
headline.main: Ten Suggestions for Rescuing the Bush Legacy

docs.lead_paragraph: Sorry, President Bush, but your legacy doesn’t look good right now. In the holiday spirit, let me offer you advice for what you can do in 2007.
docs.snippet: Sorry, President Bush, but your legacy doesn’t look good right now. In the holiday spirit, let me offer you advice for what you can do in 2007.

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL 3-14 Iraq Riveted by Execution After nearly three decades of living with the brutal repression of Saddam Hussein and the violent aftermath of his overthrow by American troops, Iraq responded with a mixture of rejoicing, violence and muted reflection to the news that their former dictator had been hanged in one of the grimmest of his own execution chambers. 1 Saddam Hussein never bowed his head, until his neck snapped, several of the witnesses present at his execution said. His last words were equally defiant: ''Down with the traitors, the Americans, the spies and the Persians.'' 1 After the hanging of Saddam Hussein, Western politicians sought a cautious balance between revulsion at his record, support for his executioners and concern at the use of a death penalty they shun in their own countries. 12 Battle Looms in Somalia A phalanx of Ethiopian tanks and armored personnel carriers chugged toward Kismayo, the last city occupied by Somalia's diminished Islamist movement, witnesses said, while the Islamists inside the city dug in and vowed never to surrender. 4 Starvation and Obesity in India Presenting a confounding portrait of child health in India, new research finds that despite the recent economic advances, India's share of malnourished children remains among the worst in the world even as public health officials confront what they call alarming levels of childhood obesity. 8 Israel's Growing Economy Israel, it seems, has figured out how to keep its economy charging forward, regardless of political turmoil and spasms of violence. This was Israel's third straight year of strong growth. The stock market has been hitting record highs, and unemployment is at a 10-year low. 3 NATIONAL 17-20 Review Boards Fall Short An examination of the Guantánamo military review boards by The New York Times suggests that they have fallen short as a source of due process. The prisoners have no right to a lawyer, or to see evidence, or to know the identity of their accusers. 1 House Museums Struggling Colonial Williamsburg is selling Carter's Grove, an 18th-century Georgian mansion, and the sale has turned attention on the plight of hundreds of other house museums across the country. 1 Ford's Body at the Capitol After a slow journey past the touchstones of his political life, the body of Gerald R. Ford, the 38th president of the United States, was brought to the Capitol dome, where a crowd of Washington dignitaries gathered to honor the man whose presidency encompassed one of the most tumultuous periods of American history. 19 Memorial for James Brown James Brown, the titan of rhythm and blues, soul and funk music who died Monday at 73, was celebrated in a public funeral and homecoming in Augusta, Georgia, where he got his start shining shoes and dancing for change. 17 NEW YORK/REGION 21-25 Officer Hurt in Bank Robbery An off-duty police officer was injured in a shootout after two masked men who had just robbed a bank tried to commandeer his car, triggering a spirited foot chase on a crowded Queens street, the police said. 23 Chess 25 Weather 16

headline.print_headline: New Job Title For Druggists: Diabetes Coach
headline.main: New Job Title for Druggists: Diabetes Coach

docs.lead_paragraph: A public health experiment in Asheville, N.C., is something of a ray of hope in combating diabetes.
docs.snippet: A public health experiment in Asheville, N.C., is something of a ray of hope in combating diabetes.

headline.print_headline: Study Links Obesity And Bottle-Fed Child
headline.main: Study Links Obesity and Bottle-Fed Child

docs.lead_paragraph: Far too many children are fat by preschool, and Hispanic youngsters are most at risk, according to research that is among the first to focus on children growing up in poverty.
docs.snippet: Far too many children are fat by preschool, and Hispanic youngsters are most at risk, according to research that is among the first to focus on children growing up in poverty.
